title: A Beginner's Guide to Using Pastels

steps.title: Choose your grip.
steps.content: Choose your grip. Experiment with different strokes on a scrap piece of paper first. Hold the pastel at the back end and color with the point or the edge of the tip to make thin, even lines. Press the stick down on the surface lengthwise and move it sideways to create thick, abstract lines. Hold the stick vertically near the tip and you can make thick, rounded markings. Thin lines are useful for linear objects like grass. Thick abstract lines are good for making a textured background. Big, round strokes can make cobblestones or bricks. Clean your pastels, if needed. Pour uncooked rice or sawdust in a box. Put your pastels inside. Close the box and shake it up.

steps.title: Practice blending.
steps.content: Practice blending. [1] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. Use a brush to move and blend color evenly. Try a tortillon (blending stump) for more linear blending. Try a lint-free rag for large areas. Use a paintbrush and water to blend a watercolor effect. [2] X Research source You can also use your fingers, which can push the pastel further into the grip of the paper. Another option is to use a blender or a paper tissue. [3] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022.

steps.title: Correct any mistakes.
steps.content: Correct any mistakes. Brush away excess color with a stiff-bristled brush. Rub a kneaded eraser gently over any mistakes. Try carefully scraping off pigment with a craft knife. You may want to practice this first on a scrap sheet.

steps.title: Make stencils.
steps.content: Make stencils. Cut out cardboard shapes. Trace around them with pastels on your drawing surface. Smudge the borders to achieve a “glowing” effect. [4] X Research source For example, trace the shapes of Christmas lights or hearts. This is a great project to do with kids.

steps.title: Try mixing chalk pastels with tempera paint.
steps.content: Try mixing chalk pastels with tempera paint. Color a landscape background with your chalk pastels. Dip a finger into tempera paint and rub it over your chalk drawing. Change fingers for different colors. [5] X Research source For example, make a sunset or ocean scene with pastels. Then use white paint over it. This technique is fun for children as well as adults, since it combines finger painting with drawing.

steps.title: Layer your drawing.
steps.content: Layer your drawing. Make the underpainting of your drawing. Then slowly build up layers and colors to create depth and intensity. [6] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. Add a background last to make your object really stick out with defined edges. [7] X Research source For example, draw a loose sketch of a light-colored piece of fruit. Create shading with colors. Finish up with a dark background. Another technique is to make the background first using oil pastel in one direction. Then layer more colors on top. Try both techniques and see which one works best for you! [8] X Research source Do not mix too many different colors as it can become messy and muddy. [9] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022.

steps.title: Change the temperature.
steps.content: Change the temperature. Put your artwork in the refrigerator for twenty minutes. Then warm your pastels in your hands to achieve better coverage. [10] X Research source Use this technique if your paper isn’t allowing you to add more layers.

steps.title: Try different strokes.
steps.content: Try different strokes. Draw freehand by sketching with light pressure to the edge of the pastel’s tip. Make choppy, tiny markings to achieve a stippled look. [11] X Research source Create “blanket” strokes by making thick, fast squiggles. Use thick, vertical strokes to create hatching. [12] X Research source Blanket strokes and hatching work well for backgrounds. Experiment with different strokes and pressure on a scrap sheet.

steps.title: Blend your work.
steps.content: Blend your work. [13] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. You can blend and mix colors on your paper or on a palette first. Practice using blending to make shadows and reflections. You can make a final blending with baby oil or other liquids. [14] X Research source Try the baby oil blending technique on a practice drawing first. Soak a cotton swab in baby oil. Smooth it over your work to blend. Allow it to dry overnight. Use water for a smooth wash of color. Try turpentine, linseed or other oils for oil pastels that aren’t water soluble. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Use a black pencil to outline your work.
steps.content: Use a black pencil to outline your work. Make the contours of the objects you’re drawing. Begin sketching loosely. Add a bit more pressure and shading to the areas that will be shadowed. [16] X Research source Try practicing this technique for a still life, such as a few pieces of fruit.

steps.title: Layer on the colors.
steps.content: Layer on the colors. [17] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. Color in your main color. For example, if you’re coloring an orange, give the body of the fruit its basic orange hue. Add a layer of darker color. Then apply the main color again. [18] X Research source Hold your pencil as you would a regular pencil, or a bit farther away from the tip. See which way is the most comfortable for you. Make sure to work in a way that the edge of your hand is not smearing the pastels that you have laid down. [19] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. Add accents after you’ve finished the main colors. For example, shades of brown and green for the blossom end of a fruit.

steps.title: Make highlights and deepen shadows.
steps.content: Make highlights and deepen shadows. Add texture and light or “shiny” areas with a white pencil. Use the white pencil in diagonal strokes to develop the background. Add more shadowing under your objects, if desired, with black and/or light blue. [20] X Research source For example, define the pores of a lemon with bits of white.
